title: Why are German numbers backwards? - Quora

response.answer_text: Very simple. This is the original way the numbers were. All Germanic and Slavic languages were like this. Presumably from the ancestral language (“PIE”). What happened though is that most language switched the way, probably (partially) when the numbers started to be written, it was the logical way to read then from left to right. The technology drives the language evolution. German conservatively insisted on the “right” way, i.e. the old way. Compare with the clock times. German still uses very much the “church bell clock” time - quarter to four, half four instead of “three thirty” and “three forty five” (the latter system is used only for the odd times, for example 3:33, 3:55 etc.)

Actually, it’s not “backwards”, but follows the eyes. To be able to say “twentyseven”, you must have seen before that the “2” is the tens digit. So for your mouth to say twentyseven, your eyes must have realized seven as the ones digit and two as the tens digit => twenty. This is used only with the basic numbers that are present in everyday life from ancient times and thus follow perception. Higher numbers are more abstract and don’t follow perception, but mathematical conception, even in German.

They’re only “backwards” up to 99. As soon as hundreds, thousands and higher orders are involved they are read forwards, so that when they’re combined it gets a bit mixed up: eg “Einundzwanzig millionen dreihundert fünfundvierzig tausend sechshundert achtundsiebzig”, in which the digits are read in the order 2–1–3–5–4–6–8–7. It’s not all that long ago that English used this order as well: Four and twenty blackbirds baked in a pieFour score and seven years ago …The days of our years are threescore years and ten

English must have come very close to having the numbers “backwards” also as olde English generally followed the Germanic influence. French, however, when forced upon the English by a new King and ruling class was seen as a higher form and more suitable for maths and science at that time. With better education the French form was taught in schools and colleges, but the rural folk and the uneducated held fast to the old forms for quiet a long time.

The numbering just reflects continuing procedure from 13 to 99. English: thirteen, fourteen, … and not ten three, ten four, … but after 20 they change to twenty-one, … (supposedly French influence) German (among others): dreizehn, vierzehn, … einundzwanzig, …

[A2A] If you mean to say, that starting a date with the day, follwed by the month and ending with the year is backwards, then I guess we’ll have to agree to disagree. If you meant something else… uhm… we use normal arabic numbers, so… no clue what else you could be on about.

Actually if you go back in time, you will see that the English did too. In plays from the 19th century you can hear things like five and twenty. You still have remnants of that in the numbers 13 to 19.
